It is important to note that the sex of the previous children does not affect the sex of the future children as each child is considered to be an independent event.

question.text: To reliably insert a DNA segment into a plasmid vector, a restriction enzyme must first be used on a palindromic sequence called a recognition site. Which of the following sequences would be ideal for this purpose?

explanation.concept_text: A palindromic sequence is one in which the nucleic acid sequence of a given strand and its complementary strand is the same when both are read in the same direction, (5’-3’). An example is given below. 3’-GGATCC-5’ 5’-CCTAGG-3’ When the given strand (first strand) is read in the 5’-3’ direction, its sequence is “CCTAGG”. When its complementary strand (second strand) is read in the 5’-3’ direction, its sequence is “CCTAGG”. Since the strands have the same 5’-3’ sequence, we can conclude that this is a palindromic sequence. The following is NOT an example of a palindromic sequence. 3’-CATAC-5’ 5’-GTATG-3’ When the given strand (first strand) is read in the 5’-3’ direction, its sequence is “CATAC”. When its complementary strand (second strand) is read in the 5’-3’ direction, its sequence is “GTATG”. Since the strands do not have the same 5’-3’ sequence, we can conclude that this is not a palindromic sequence. Restriction enzymes are enzymes that cut DNA at specific sites (recognition sites) that contain a palindromic sequence. There is only one palindromic sequence in the answer choices. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer. Quick Tip : We can quickly eliminate Option B because it includes the nucleic acid uracil (U) which is present only in RNA, while restriction enzymes only cut DNA.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 3’-CAACTTG-5’; 5’-GTTGAAC-3’ – This option is incorrect because the sequence is not palindromic. When the first strand is read in the 5’-3’ direction, its sequence is “GTTCAAC”. When the second strand is read in the 5’-3’ direction, its sequence is “CAAGTTG”. Since the strands do not have the same 5’-3’ sequence, we can conclude that this is NOT a palindromic sequence. Option B. 3’-AUGAUGAUG-5’; 5’-UACUACUAC-3’ – This option is incorrect because the sequence is not palindromic. When the first strand is read in the 5’-3’ direction, its sequence is “GUAGUAGUA”. When the second strand is read in the 5’-3’ direction, its sequence is “UACUACUAC”. Since the strands do not have the same 5’-3’ sequence, we can conclude that this is NOT a palindromic sequence. Furthermore, this option includes the nucleic acid uracil (U) which is present only in RNA, while restriction enzymes only cut DNA. Option D. 3’-GCTAATCG-5’; 5’-CGATTAGC-3’ – This option is incorrect because the sequence is not palindromic. When the first strand is read in the 5’-3’ direction, its sequence is “GCTAATCG”. When the second strand is read in the 5’-3’ direction, its sequence is “CGATTAGC”. Since the strands do not have the same 5’-3’ sequence, we can conclude that this is NOT a palindromic sequence. Option E. 3’-TTTAAAGGG-5’; 5’-AAATTTCCC -3’ – This option is incorrect because the sequence is not palindromic. When the first strand is read in the 5’-3’ direction, its sequence is “GGGAAATTT”. When the second strand is read in the 5’-3’ direction, its sequence is “AAATTTCCC”. Since the strands do not have the same 5’-3’ sequence, we can conclude that this is NOT a palindromic sequence.

question.text: For a gene in equilibrium, a researcher determined that the dominant allele had a frequency of 0.40 while the recessive allele had a frequency of 0.60. What is the frequency of heterozygotes for this gene?

explanation.concept_text: For genes in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, the Hardy-Weinberg model enables us to relate the allele frequencies to the allele combination frequencies. We can determine the frequency of homozygous and heterozygous individuals for the gene in question. The Hardy-Weinberg model is as follows: p + q = 1 p 2 + 2pq + q 2 = 1 Here, p is the frequency of the dominant allele and q is the frequency of the recessive allele. The first part of this model describes how the only alleles present are the dominant and recessive alleles so the sum of their individual allele frequencies must be 1. The second part of this model describes how the probability of being homozygous for the dominant allele, heterozygous, and homozygous for the recessive allele must add to 1. In other words, all members of the population are either homozygous dominant (p 2 ), heterozygous (2pq), or homozygous recessive (q 2 ) for this particular gene. First, we examine the allele frequencies of the dominant and recessive alleles and verify that they sum up to 1. This indicates to us that these are the only alleles present for the gene in question. Here, we have 0.40 for the dominant allele and 0.60 for the recessive allele which indeed sums up to 1. Next, we calculate the frequency of the heterozygous individual. In the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, heterozygotes are represented by 2pq. In our case, this is equal to 2×0.4×0.6=0.48. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 0.12 – This option is incorrect because by using the equation p 2 + 2pq + q 2 , we know that the term, 2pq, represents the frequency of heterozygous individuals. Therefore, we can plug in the values of p = 0.4 and q = 0.6 into the 2pq term to get 2(0.4)(0.6) = 0.48. Option B. 0.20 – This option is incorrect because by using the equation p 2 + 2pq + q 2 , we know that the term, 2pq, represents the frequency of heterozygous individuals. Therefore, we can plug in the values of p = 0.4 and q = 0.6 into the 2pq term to get 2(0.4)(0.6) = 0.48. Option C. 0.24 – This option is incorrect because by using the equation p 2 + 2pq + q 2 , we know that the term, 2pq, represents the frequency of heterozygous individuals. Therefore, we can plug in the values of p = 0.4 and q = 0.6 into the 2pq term to get 2(0.4)(0.6) = 0.48. Option E. 0.50 – This option is incorrect because by using the equation p 2 + 2pq + q 2 , we know that the term, 2pq, represents the frequency of heterozygous individuals. Therefore, we can plug in the values of p = 0.4 and q = 0.6 into the 2pq term to get 2(0.4)(0.6) = 0.48.

question.text: Which of the following is the product of spermatogenesis?

explanation.concept_text: Spermatogenesis describes the meiotic cell divisions that produce sperm. The process that begins at puberty in males and occurs within the seminiferous tubules in the testes. Spermatogonia cells, proliferative cells in the testes that are the precursor cells for mature sperm, undergo mitosis to form primary spermatocytes. These primary spermatocytes then undergo meiosis. Meiosis I produces two secondary spermatocytes and meiosis II produces four spermatids. Spermatids are then nourished by Sertoli cells in the seminiferous tubules and they develop into spermatozoa , also known as mature sperm. This process is called spermiogenesis and is a part of spermatogenesis. The mature sperm cells are then released from the supporting Sertoli cells into the lumen of the seminiferous tubules, which is called spermiation. The sperm cells are then stored in the epididymis where they complete maturation and gain motility. Since spermatogenesis produces spermatozoa (mature sperm), Option E is correct. The image below provides illustrations of spermatogenesis in addition to a cross-section of a seminiferous tubule where these processes take place. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Primary spermatocytes – This option is incorrect because primary spermatocytes are produced during an intermediary step of spermatogenesis. They are produced when the diploid spermatogonium cells undergo mitosis. The primary spermatocytes will then proceed to enter the process of meiosis. Option B. Spermatogonia – This option is incorrect because spermatogonia are the starting diploid cells of spermatogenesis. Spermatogonia are an example of germ cells that give rise to gametes. Option C. Secondary spermatocytes – This option is incorrect because secondary spermatocytes are produced during an intermediary step of spermatogenesis. They are produced when the diploid primary spermatocytes undergo meiosis I. Once this occurs, there are now two haploid secondary spermatocytes. These secondary spermatocytes will then proceed to enter the process of meiosis II where they become four spermatids. Option D. Spermatids – This option is incorrect because spermatids are present prior to spermiogenesis, the final step of spermatogenesis. Spermatids, produced from secondary spermatocytes via meiosis II, are nourished by Sertoli cells to differentiate into spermatozoa, also known as mature sperm.

question.text: Non-stem cells have a limit to the number of rounds of cell division they can go through due to which of the following?

options.label: E.
options.text: Theory of inheritance of acquired characteristics

explanation.concept_text: The Hayflick limit pertains to the limited number of times a cell can undergo division until it has to stop and undergo apoptosis. This arises from the concept of telomere shortening , which is the shortening of DNA with each round of replication. Telomeres are DNA sequences found at the ends of chromosomes that are added to prevent the loss of important genomic information when chromosome ends get shorter. This is due to the way that the lagging strand works. DNA polymerase needs 3’-OH to start replicating, and after all RNA primers are removed, there is always an un-replicated region at the end of the strand. This is genetic information that is lost and provides a reason why telomeres shorten with each round of replication. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Wobble Effect – This option is incorrect the Wobble Effect explains flexibility in the identity of the third nucleotide in a codon. The Wobble Effect describes how one amino acid can be coded for by several different codons. Hence, it minimizes the damage that can be caused by a misreading of a codon. For example, if the codon CUU, coding for the amino acid leucine, was misread as CUC, CUA, or CUG during transcription, the codon will still be translated as leucine. Option B. Genetic drift – This option is incorrect because genetic drift describes the change in allele frequency that occurs due to the random movement of members of a population. Genetic drift is particularly susceptible to occurring in small populations that already have a low number of members. Genetic drift is a way to describe gene changes in populations whereas the question asks about a phenomenon that occurs in an individual, particularly related to its cell division and replication. Option C. Genetic equilibrium – This option is incorrect because genetic equilibrium is a state where allele frequencies do not change with time and thus no evolution is occurring. Genetic equilibrium is also known as the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. Since genetic equilibrium is used to describe populations, this answer choice cannot be correct as the question asks about a phenomenon that occurs in an individual, particularly related to its cell division and replication. Option E. Theory of inheritance of acquired characteristics – This option is incorrect because this answer choice is describing Lamarck’s theory which states that body features acquired during one‘s lifetime can be passed down to their offspring. For example, a giraffe that developed a long neck to reach and eat from tall trees can pass that acquired characteristic to their offspring. However, it is important to note that this is a discredited theory of evolution and that this answer choice is further incorrect because evolution applies to populations and not specific individuals.

question.text: tRNA is necessary to link together __________.

explanation.concept_text: Gene expression is the process of converting a gene into a protein product through the steps: transcription and translation. DNA is converted to RNA through transcription and RNA is converted to proteins through translation. During translation, amino acids are added to a growing chain to form a functional protein. Translation , specifically, involves using mRNA as a template to produce a polypeptide that may fold into a protein. The ribosome holds the mRNA. The particular sequence of three nucleic acids, or codon, is “read” by the ribosome and tRNA (transfer RNA) with the corresponding amino acid for that codon delivers the amino acid to the ribosome for polymerization. This process is known as translation because genetic information is translated from the language of nucleic acids to the language of amino acids and proteins. The process of translation is illustrated below. Based on codon readings, tRNA delivers corresponding amino acids to ribosomes for amino acid polymerization. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Monosaccharides – This option is incorrect because the linking of monosaccharides is done by dehydration/condensation reactions that remove water molecules and thus form glycosidic bonds between monosaccharides. tRNA is not involved in the process of polymerizing monosaccharides. Option C. Ribonucleic acids – This option is incorrect because the linking of ribonucleic acids (RNA) is done by an enzyme called RNA polymerase during RNA synthesis as part of transcription. RNA polymerase synthesizes RNA molecules from a template of DNA. tRNA is not involved in the process of polymerizing ribonucleic acids. Option D. Deoxyribonucleic acids – This option is incorrect because the linking of deoxyribonucleic acids (DNA) is done by an enzyme called DNA polymerase. DNA polymerase synthesizes DNA molecules from nucleotides. tRNA is not involved in the process of polymerizing deoxyribonucleic acids. Option E. Genes – This option is incorrect because genes are arranged on DNA chromosomes with each gene having its unique position called a locus. Genes are not “linked” together by a process and exist along a chromosome in a specific order. (Note that the concept of “linked genes” is different from the process of “linking” described in the question. The process of “linking” described in the question refers to two separate molecules connecting with one another by forming a bond.)

question.text: Which of the following scientists proposed the theory of trait inheritance through use and disuse?

explanation.concept_text: Lamarck proposed that traits are inherited by offspring based on the use or disuse of these traits. Traits that are used would be strengthened and readily passed on to offspring while traits that were in disuse would weaken and be less prominent in offspring if present at all. However, this theory was disproved because evolution applies to populations and not specific individuals. For example, the offspring of athletes are not necessarily any fitter than the offspring of non-athletes If Lamarck‘s theory were to be correct, then the offspring of athletes should be fitter than the offspring of non-athletes because athletes with good physique would be able to pass on strong physical traits to their offspring. Physical characteristics themselves cannot be passed onto offspring; only genes can be passed on. Therefore, Option A is best associated with the theory of use and disuse. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Darwin – This option is incorrect because Darwin proposed the theory of natural selection, also known as “survival of the fittest”, to explain evolution. This theory proposed that due to competition for limited resources, traits that enabled a species to produce more viable offspring were passed down. In other words, alleles that provide a reproductive advantage will be selected for and become more common from one generation to the next. Alleles that are disadvantageous will be selected against and become less common. Over time, populations become more adapted to their environment. Option C. Cuvier – This option is incorrect because Cuvier proposed the theory of catastrophism where major natural disasters shaped the structure and types of life on Earth. In other words, the alleles that managed to survive extinction would reproduce and be passed on to offspring. Therefore, the particular traits depend on what traits are randomly driven to extinction and what traits are spared by the catastrophe. While catastrophes can play a role in driving evolution, they fail to explain the gradual evolutionary changes shown in fossil records to the same extent as other theories, such as Darwin's Theory of Natural Selection. Option D. Mendel – This option is incorrect because Mendel experimented with pea plants to explore the nature of inheritance. From this research, he put forth the laws of inheritance that described how alleles were inherited. Mendel proposed that heritable factors (genes) come in pairs (alleles) that are independently inherited, one allele from each parent. Option E. Wallace – This option is incorrect because Wallace co-authored research with Darwin regarding evolution and natural selection. He independently proposed the theory of natural selection as well, then built the theory up with Darwin’s work which led to the more comprehensive theory of natural selection as we understand it today.

question.text: A certain species of remora can attach itself to a shark and consume fecal matter from the shark for nutrients. If the remora neither harms nor benefits the shark, what best describes the relationship between the two?

explanation.concept_text: Symbiosis is a close relationship formed between two species for an extended period of time. Examples of symbiosis are shown in the image below. Commensalism is one such relationship where one species benefits from the relationship but does not affect the other species whether positively or negatively. The remora obtains nutrients from the shark’s fecal matter, but the shark is neither positively nor negatively affected by the remora. Since one species benefits from the relationship while the relationship is neutral to the other species, this is an example of commensalism. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Amensalism – This option is incorrect because amensalism is NOT a form of symbiosis. Amensalism is an interaction between two species in which one species is harmed or killed by the other, but the other species is unaffected. Neither species is harmed in the relationship described in the question. The interaction between Penicillium and Staphylococcus is an example of amensalism. While Penicillium secretes penicillin that kills bacteria including Staphylococcus, Penicillium is unaffected by the interaction. Option B. Parasitism – This option is incorrect because parasitism is a form of symbiosis in which one species benefits itself at the expense of another species. The remora as described above does not benefit at the expense of the shark. Tapeworms, leeches, lice, and fleas all demonstrate parasitism. These organisms live inside another organism and thrives at the cost of their host, who is damaged by the interaction. Option C. Mutualism – This option is incorrect because mutualism is a form of symbiosis in which both species benefit from their interactions. There is no mutual benefit in the relationship between the remora and the shark as described above. While the remora benefits from the relationship, the shark is neither positively nor negatively affected by the relationship. The interaction between ants and aphids are an example of mutualism. While ants gain nutrients by feeding on the honeydew of aphids, in return aphids are protected from predators and parasites by the ants on them.

question.text: The process of photosynthesis can be summarized as follows: 6CO 2 + 6H 2 O → C 6 H 12 O 6 + 6O 2 Which process is ultimately responsible for the production of oxygen?

explanation.concept_text: The light-dependent reactions in the chloroplast of plants involve a light-driven electron transport chain. As electrons flow through the photosystems, they must be replenished at the start of the chain. Water is the source of these electrons. As two electrons are lost when passed to a primary electron accepter from photosystem II, water is split into two H + ions, one O 2 molecule, and two electrons to replenish the lost electrons. The two electrons enter the electron transport chain of the light-dependent reactions. In the absence of water, there is no continued source of electrons and the light-dependent reactions cannot proceed. This process of water splitting is called photolysis . Since the splitting of water produces oxygen during the process of photosynthesis, Option B is the correct answer. The flow of electrons starting from water in the light-dependent reactions is shown in the image below. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Breakdown of glucose – This option is incorrect because glucose does not break down in the process of photosynthesis. Glucose, instead, is a product of photosynthesis during the dark reaction. Photosynthesis is a process that ultimately harnesses light energy to synthesize glucose that can be used by plants for energy. Option C. Splitting of CO 2 – This option is incorrect because CO 2 does not split during the processes of photosynthesis, but rather joins with ribulose bisphosphate (RuBP) in order to “fix” CO 2 during the Calvin Cycle. The Calvin Cycle is the dark reaction that fixes 6 CO 2 molecules through a cycle that repeats 6 times to synthesize glucose. Oxygen is not a product of the Calvin Cycle. Option D. Breakdown of mesophylls – This option is incorrect because the mesophyll layer of the leaves does not break down during photosynthesis, and it also does not produce oxygen as a by-product. Mesophyll cells of plant leaves are the location of carbon fixation during C3 photosynthesis. Option E. Aerobic respiration – This option is incorrect because aerobic respiration is the opposite of photosynthesis where glucose and oxygen are used up in order to generate energy in the form of ATP, a process that also produces CO 2 and H 2 O.

question.text: Honeybees and ants secrete a trail of a chemical factor after locating a source of food, allowing them to communicate the location of the food to others. This form of communication is accomplished using which type of compound?

explanation.concept_text: One of the modes of communication utilized by animals is chemical communication via pheromones . Unlike hormones, pheromones, are chemicals released into the environment for communication with other animals. Hence, pheromones can act as alarm symbols, territory/nest/food markers, sex attractants, etc. Since the question describes honeybees and ants secreting a chemical to communicate the location of food with others, Option A is the correct answer. Pheromones can be detected through various means including smelling and ingestion. Depending on the chemical, they may result in a variety of different effects. Releaser pheromones trigger a reversible, short-term response. For example, ants use formic acid, a releaser pheromone, to mark a trail to food. Primer pheromones trigger long-term physiological and behavioral changes in development. For example, a queen bee can release a chemical to prevent the development of reproductive capabilities. Other pheromones include trail pheromones that mark a path to a nest or food source and territorial pheromones such as those in dog urine that mark territory.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Hormone – This option is incorrect because hormones are signaling molecules produced for communication among the various organs of a multicellular organism. Hormones are released within the bloodstream of a single organism, and are not released externally to communicate with other organisms. Pheromones are NOT hormones because pheromones refer to chemicals used for communication between organisms. Option C. Neurotransmitter – This option is incorrect because neurotransmitters are signaling molecules released by neurons to act on other neurons or target tissue. While neurotransmitters function within an organism, pheromones function between different organisms. Option D. Primary messenger – This option is incorrect because primary messengers are extracellular signaling molecules including hormones that bind to membrane receptors to trigger some intracellular response. They do not function outside of an organism. Option E. Secondary messenger – This option is incorrect because secondary messengers are intracellular signaling molecules activated in response to a primary messenger. They act within a cell to propagate an extracellular signal to the inside of the cell. They do not function outside a multicellular organism or even outside an individual cell. Examples of secondary messengers include cAMP, IP 3 , DAG, and Calcium.

question.text: A researcher introduces a chemical into a tumor cell that has begun to replicate out of control. After introducing the chemical, the formation of microtubules is stabilized and they are no longer able to shorten. What phase of the cell cycle has been disrupted?

explanation.concept_text: Cell division , the process by which a parent cell divides into two daughter cells, is split into two distinct parts: interphase and mitosis. During interphase, the cell prepares for division during three phases: G 1 , S, and G 2 . During the G-phases the cell grows in size in preparation for division, and during S phase the cell replicates its DNA. When the cell is truly ready for division, it enters mitosis. Mitosis describes cell division in all somatic cells and involves the processes of prophase, metaphase, anaphase, telophase, and cytokinesis. Mitosis is most affected by microtubule-inhibiting chemicals because the mitotic spindle (made of microtubules) is key in cell division. The mitotic spindle is directly involved in moving chromosomes around the eukaryotic cell. During anaphase, the microtubules shorten and pull the chromosomes towards opposite ends of the cell. Since the chemical discussed in the question stabilizes the formation of microtubules and prevents them from shortening, the cell will not be able to proceed with anaphase and complete cell division. Therefore, Option E is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. G 0 Phase – This option is incorrect because this is a stasis phase where the cell no longer undergoes division. Since the chemical interrupts microtubule shortening which is necessary to split the centromere and move the sister chromatids to opposite poles of the cells during anaphase of mitosis, the G 0 phase is not affected by the chemical as no microtubules are involved in G 0 . Option B. G 1 Phase – This option is incorrect because this is a phase where the cell undergoes its main period of growth. Since the chemical interrupts microtubule shortening which is necessary to split the centromere and move the sister chromatids to opposite poles of the cells during anaphase of mitosis, the G 1 phase is not affected by the chemical as no microtubules are involved in G 1 . Option C. G 2 Phase – This option is incorrect because this is a phase where the cell begins to prepare for mitosis by replicating its organelles. Since the chemical interrupts microtubule shortening which is necessary to split the centromere and move the sister chromatids to opposite poles of the cells during anaphase of mitosis, the G 2 phase is not affected by the chemical as no microtubules are involved in G 2 . Option D. S Phase – This option is incorrect because this is a phase where the cell undergoes the replication of its DNA in preparation for mitosis. Since the chemical interrupts microtubule shortening which is necessary to split the centromere and move the sister chromatids to opposite poles of the cells during the anaphase of mitosis, the S phase is not affected by the chemical as no microtubules are involved in the S phase.

question.text: Which of the following best describes the actions of ADH?

options.label: A.
options.text: Acts on collecting duct by increasing reabsorption of water

options.label: B.
options.text: Acts on distal convoluted tubule by increasing excretion of sodium

options.label: C.
options.text: Acts on collecting duct by decreasing permeability to water

options.label: D.
options.text: Acts on Loop of Henle to increase water reabsorption

options.label: E.
options.text: Acts on proximal convoluted tubule by decreasing permeability to water

correct_answer_text: Acts on collecting duct by increasing reabsorption of water

explanation.concept_text: ADH , or antidiuretic hormone , is a hormone that controls the amount of water in the body. It is produced by the hypothalamus of the brain and is then stored and secreted from the posterior pituitary. It is released in response to low blood volume. The kidney is made up of many nephrons, as seen in the image below, which filters blood and produces a filtrate that goes through collecting ducts to be excreted as urine. ADH acts on these collecting ducts to increase the number of aquaporin channels which allow more water to leave the urine and become reabsorbed by the cells of the collecting duct. Hence, ADH makes the urine more concentrated by facilitating the transport of water out of urine and into the cells of the collecting duct. That water is eventually brought back to the bloodstream, raising the blood volume. ADH also acts on the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron, though its effect is greatest on the collecting duct. Since ADH acts on the collecting duct to increase its reabsorption of water, Option A is correct. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Acts on distal convoluted tubule by increasing excretion of sodium – This option is incorrect because ADH does not act to increase the excretion of sodium. Although ADH can act on the distal convoluted tubule, it does so by promoting the reabsorption of water. Option C. Acts on collecting duct by decreasing permeability to water – This option is incorrect because ADH does not act to decrease the collecting duct’s permeability to water, but rather increases its permeability. ADH causes an increase in aquaporins which allows more water to leave from the urine and enter the cells in the collecting duct. Option D. Acts on Loop of Henle to increase water reabsorption – This option is incorrect because even though ADH does act to increase water reabsorption, ADH does not act on the Loop of Henle; it acts on the collecting duct. The Loop of Henle, making up a majority of the nephron, consists of the descending and ascending loops. The descending loop is permeable to water; hence, water leaves and the solute concentration in the tube increases. The descending loop of Henle allows organisms to reabsorb water; the longer the loop of Henle, the more water an organism can reclaim. The ascending loop then pumps out NaCl, causing the solute concentration in the tube to decrease. Option E. Acts on proximal convoluted tubule by decreasing permeability to water – This option is incorrect because ADH does not act to decrease water permeability, but rather increases water permeability. Furthermore, ADH does not act on the proximal convoluted tubule and, in fact, acts primarily on the collecting duct.

question.text: Which part of the digestive system functions to absorb water, electrolytes, and bacteria-produced Vitamin K?

explanation.concept_text: The main functions of the large intestine are the absorption of water, electrolytes, and vitamins. The absorption of water in the colon of the large intestine concentrates the indigestible material, producing feces that are stored in the rectum. The large intestine also absorbs electrolytes through its ion channels. Furthermore, symbiotic bacteria in the large intestine produce vitamin K and B12 that can be absorbed in the intestines. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer. The roles of the different segments of the digestive system are summarized below. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Stomach – This option is incorrect because the stomach does not carry out the absorption of water or nutrients. The stomach is the site of mechanical and chemical digestion of food (particularly proteins). The muscles in the stomach are activated to break down food. The stomach also secretes gastric juice, containing digestive enzymes and HCl, to break down food that enters the stomach. Option B. Ileum – This option is incorrect because while the jejunum and the ileum that follows are the primary sites of nutrient absorption and some water absorption occurs as well, mineral absorption does not occur in these sites. Aside from the absorption of nutrients, the ileum also contains Peyer’s patches which are large aggregates of lymphoid tissue. Furthermore, the ileum is a part of the small intestine. Since there is no bacteria-produced vitamin K in the small intestine, this option is incorrect. Option D. Duodenum – This option is incorrect because the duodenum is the site of continuing digestion by pancreatic digestive enzymes and bile from the liver. The duodenum breaks down starch and proteins as well as other food types such as fats and nucleotides. Hence, very little if any absorption occurs in the duodenum. Furthermore, the duodenum is a part of the small intestine. Since there is no bacteria-produced vitamin K in the small intestine, this option is incorrect. Option E. Jejunum – This option is incorrect because while the jejunum and the ileum that follows are the primary sites of nutrient absorption and some water absorption occurs as well, mineral absorption does not occur in these sites. Furthermore, the jejunum is a part of the small intestine. Since there is no bacteria-produced vitamin K in the small intestine, this option is incorrect.
